findings:
1) Definition: In Voiculescu’s non-microstates framework, for one selfadjoint variable X, free Fisher information is \(\Phi^*(X)=\|J(X)\|_2^2\), where \(J(X)\) is the conjugate variable. If the law of X has density \(\rho\), then (up to Hilbert-transform normalization convention) \(J(X)\) is the Hilbert-transform field evaluated at X, so \(\Phi^*(X)\) is the \(L^2(\rho)\)-norm of that field.
2) Proof structure of free Stam: The core Stam inequality is proved directly at the conjugate-variable level, not by a Dyson/free-Brownian-time monotonicity argument. The key steps are: (i) identify \(J(X+Y)\) as a conditional expectation of relative conjugate variables; (ii) use \(L^2\)-contractivity of conditional expectation; (iii) use freeness to simplify relative conjugate variables and kill cross terms; (iv) optimize a scalar parameter. Free Brownian motion and free entropy/heat-flow identities are used elsewhere in the paper (de Bruijn-type relations, entropy results), but are not the essential mechanism for Stam itself.
3) Key calculation: For any \(\alpha\in[0,1]\),
\(J(X+Y)=E_{W^*(X+Y)}[\alpha J(X{:}Y)+(1-\alpha)J(Y{:}X)]\).
Then
\(\Phi^*(X+Y)=\|J(X+Y)\|_2^2\le \|\alpha J(X{:}Y)+(1-\alpha)J(Y{:}X)\|_2^2\).
If X,Y are free, \(J(X{:}Y)=J(X)\), \(J(Y{:}X)=J(Y)\), and mixed inner product vanishes, giving
\(\Phi^*(X+Y)\le \alpha^2\Phi^*(X)+(1-\alpha)^2\Phi^*(Y)\).
Optimizing \(\alpha=\Phi^*(Y)/(\Phi^*(X)+\Phi^*(Y))\) yields
\(\Phi^*(X+Y)\le \frac{\Phi^*(X)\Phi^*(Y)}{\Phi^*(X)+\Phi^*(Y)}\), i.e.
\(\frac1{\Phi^*(X+Y)}\ge \frac1{\Phi^*(X)}+\frac1{\Phi^*(Y)}\).
4) Where freeness is used specifically: (a) identifying relative conjugate variables with ordinary conjugate variables (e.g. \(J(X{:}Y)=J(X)\)); (b) orthogonality/vanishing mixed term in the \(L^2\)-norm expansion; (c) the conditional expectation identities are formulated over algebras generated by free variables. These are the genuinely noncommutative/free inputs.
Note: I did not run MO/MSE searches in this turn (per your instruction to avoid tool calls), so MO/MSE-specific proof attributions remain to be cross-checked separately.

findings:
On the Weyl chamber \(\lambda_1<\cdots<\lambda_n\), define \(S_i=\sum_{j
eq i}(\lambda_i-\lambda_j)^{-1}\) and \(\Phi_n=\sum_i S_i^2\). A key simplification is the exact identity \(\Phi_n=2\sum_{i<j}(\lambda_i-\lambda_j)^{-2}\), since triple cross-terms cancel by \(\sum_{cyc} rac{1}{(\lambda_i-\lambda_j)(\lambda_i-\lambda_k)}=0\). For Dyson BM \(d\lambda_i= rac{1}{\sqrt n}dB_i+ rac1n S_i dt\), It\^o for \(F=1/\Phi_n\) gives a local martingale plus drift \(L F\), where \(L= rac1{2n}\Delta+ rac1n\sum_i S_i\partial_i\). With \(U_k=\sum_{j
eq k}(\lambda_k-\lambda_j)^{-3}\), \(V_k=\sum_{j
eq k}(\lambda_k-\lambda_j)^{-4}\), one gets \(\partial_k\Phi_n=-4U_k\), \(\partial_{kk}\Phi_n=12V_k\), hence an explicit drift formula for \(F\). Pathwise sign is never definite because of the martingale term. For expectation, \( rac{d}{dt}\mathbb E[F_t]=\mathbb E[L F_t]\), but the integrand is not sign-definite in general: for \(n=3\), \(\lambda=(-1,0,1)\), \(L(1/\Phi_n)=-1/27<0\); for \(n=2\), \(L(1/\Phi_2)=3/2>0\). So this direct monotonicity route does not yield a universal nonnegative integrand.

findings:
1) Exact identification with standard Dyson Brownian motion is not available. The law of A+UBU* (U Haar) is an orbital-sum law with fixed perturbation spectrum mu, while A+sqrt(t)GUE has Gaussian matrix increments and random perturbation spectrum. A hard obstruction: for X=A+UBU*, all invariants tr((X-A)^k)=tr(B^k) are deterministic, but for X_t=A+sqrt(t)GUE they are random. So no deterministic stopped Dyson time t* gives the same matrix law. A conditional/Doob-transform version is plausible: Dyson/matrix Brownian motion conditioned to hit the conjugacy class of B at time t* (or equivalently Brownian bridge on U(n) pushed by U->A+UBU*) can realize the target law, but this is a different process.
2) HCIZ gives a principled route to E_U[f(eigs(A+UBU*))], hence to f=1/Phi_n. One can write an orbital convolution density rho_{A,B}(nu) on the Weyl chamber (Horn polytope support), derived from HCIZ/Fourier inversion, then integrate f against rho_{A,B}. This is mathematically clean but computationally difficult for general n because rho is piecewise-polynomial/distributional across Horn walls and 1/Phi_n is highly nonlinear.
3) Finite-n analog of subordination: no known exact analytic finite-n subordination pair omega_{1,n},omega_{2,n} matching Biane’s free identity in full generality. What is established is exact linearization via finite free cumulants (Marcus framework), which is algebraic rather than analytic subordination. So this direction is promising for structure but currently a gap for a Stam-type Fisher-information inequality.
4) Relation between E_U[1/Phi_n(A+UBU*)] and 1/Phi_n(p boxplus_n q): they are different functionals (expectation after nonlinear map on random polynomial/eigenvalues vs nonlinear map after averaging coefficients). Jensen gives a direction only if T(P):=1/Phi_n(P) is convex/concave on a chosen linear parameterization (e.g., coefficients). If T is convex, T(E[P_U])<=E[T(P_U)]; if concave, reverse. At present, no global convexity/concavity is known, so no unconditional Jensen direction can be asserted.

findings: Established (analytic, n=3 root-coordinates): the map \(p\mapsto 1/\Phi_n(p)\) is not globally convex or concave even on the convex Weyl chamber of ordered roots, so Jensen has no fixed direction. For \(n=3\), with gaps \(s=\lambda_2-\lambda_1>0\), \(t=\lambda_3-\lambda_2>0\), \(f(s,t)=1/\Phi_3\) has a 1D slice \(f(r,1)\) whose second derivative changes sign (positive near \(r=0\), negative at \(r=1\)). Hence neither \(\mathbb E[f(P_U)]\ge f(\mathbb E[P_U])\) nor the reverse is universally valid. This directly resolves the Jensen-direction obstacle: the Dyson/It\^o quantity \(\mathbb E[1/\Phi_n(\chi_{A+UBU^*})]\) cannot be converted to \(1/\Phi_n(\mathbb E\chi_{A+UBU^*})\) by convexity/concavity. Also, coefficient-space convexity is structurally awkward because the monic real-rooted locus is not convex. Plausible extension: the same failure persists for \(n\ge4\) and in finite cumulant coordinates. Important correction: convexity in cumulants plus \(f(0)=0\) does not by itself imply superadditivity \(f(x+y)\ge f(x)+f(y)\) (especially for degree-2 homogeneous functionals like \(1/\Phi_n\)). Recommended path is to bypass Jensen entirely and work directly on the expected polynomial via MSS coefficient bilinearity / finite-cumulant additivity, as your \(n=3\) surplus identity already does.
key_formulas: \text{Jensen directions: convex }f\Rightarrow \mathbb E f(X)\ge f(\mathbb E X),\ \text{concave }f\Rightarrow \mathbb E f(X)\le f(\mathbb E X);\ \text{here neither applies globally.}
\text{MSS coefficient bilinearity (monic basis): }c_k=\sum_{i+j=k} w_n(i,j,k)\,a_i b_j,\quad w_n(i,j,k)=\frac{(n-i)!(n-j)!}{n!(n-k)!}.

findings: Attempt (a) via Dyson/Itô can be set up but does not close. A natural interpolation is to run unitary Brownian motion on the orbit of B and study P_t(x)=E[det(xI-A-U_tBU_t^*)], with P_\infty=p\boxplus_n q. Using HCIZ/Weingarten expansions, the first-order coefficient evolution is consistent with MSS bilinear weights and finite-free-cumulant additivity heuristics. However, the critical Stam step fails: \Phi_n is defined from roots of P_t (roots of an averaged characteristic polynomial), while Dyson SDE controls sample eigenvalues of det(xI-A-U_tBU_t^*) before averaging. There is no closed SDE/PDE for those averaged roots, so the Itô drift of \Phi_n(P_t) cannot be expressed in a sign-definite form. Equivalent convexity route (b) also stalls: for n\ge4, 1/\Phi_n is a highly nonlocal rational function of coefficients/cumulants with essential mixed terms, and no global concavity/Brunn-Minkowski-type certificate is available. So the proof is incomplete; the exact obstruction is the missing finite-dimensional analogue of the free score/subordination/de Bruijn package that Voiculescu uses.

next_steps: To finish the conjecture, one new input appears necessary: either (1) a finite free score/subordination identity yielding a conditional-expectation contraction for \Phi_n under \boxplus_n, or (2) a hyperbolic-polynomial/mixed-discriminant inequality proving global concavity of 1/\Phi_n along MSS coefficient geodesics. A concrete next target is n=4: derive an exact symbolic expression for \Delta_4:=1/\Phi_4(p\boxplus_4 q)-1/\Phi_4(p)-1/\Phi_4(q), clear denominators using discriminants, and seek an SOS or Lorentzian certificate; success there would likely reveal the missing general mechanism.

findings:
1) Proof viability assessment: estimated 25-40% for a full unconditional proof for all n>=4 in the next cycle; ~70% for a conditional theorem ("if Lemma A+B then Stam"); >90% for additional verified small-n cases (n=4 exactly, maybe n=5 with heavy computation). The conjecture itself looks likely true from n=2,3 proofs plus numerics through n=8.

2) Most promising route: induction/differentiation is currently the best path. It is closest to Voiculescu's mechanism (flow + Fisher dissipation), but avoids the hardest Dyson-Brownian mismatch between random eigenvalue SDEs and roots of an averaged characteristic polynomial. Direct algebraic elimination appears least scalable beyond n=4.

3) Precise blockers:
Blocker A (finite de Bruijn identity): Need a finite entropy functional H_n such that along a finite-free heat flow p_t, d/dt H_n(p_t) = -Phi_n(p_t). Likely true: medium-high. Tools: Calogero-Moser root dynamics, discriminant-based entropy candidates, generator/carre-du-champ calculations.
Blocker B (finite score/projection inequality): Need an inequality that plays the free-score projection role and yields an infinitesimal Fisher inequality for p⊞_n q. Likely true: medium. Tools: matrix-model representation, HCIZ/Weingarten identities, orthogonal projection in polynomial coefficient coordinates.
Blocker C (monotonicity/convexity step): Need to prove d/dt[1/Phi_n(p_t⊞_n q_t)-1/Phi_n(p_t)-1/Phi_n(q_t)] >= 0 (or equivalent integrated form). Likely true if A+B hold. Tools: coupled flow differentiation, Gronwall-type closure, convexity estimates.
Blocker D (algebraic positivity certificate): For fixed n (starting n=4), need Delta_n(p,q):=1/Phi_n(p⊞_n q)-1/Phi_n(p)-1/Phi_n(q) >= 0 on ordered roots. Likely true: high for small n. Tools: symmetry reduction (translation/scaling), CAD/SOS, exact rational arithmetic.

4) Fallback positions:
- Full proof for n=4 via symbolic computation/CAD after normalization.
- Conditional theorem: A+B => Stam inequality for all n.
- Asymptotic theorem: for regular sequences p_n,q_n, liminf_n Delta_n(p_n,q_n) >= 0, recovering Voiculescu in the large-n limit.
- Restricted-class proofs (e.g., one factor finite-Gaussian/Hermite, or perturbative neighborhoods of equal-spacing configurations).

5) Connection to known results: This inequality does not appear to be already established under another standard name. It is a genuine finite-dimensional analogue of free Stam (Voiculescu 1998), and is not implied by MSS real-rootedness/interlacing alone. It is consistent with (and heuristically converges to) free Stam as n→∞ under appropriate scaling.

6) Recommended next actions:
(1) Write a conditional "finite Stam" theorem with explicit lemma dependencies (A,B,C).
(2) Fix a concrete finite heat-flow model and attempt exact derivation of Blocker A.
(3) Run an n=4 exact positivity program (normalized variables, rational certificates).
(4) Build a perturbative expansion around finite-Gaussian input to test Blocker C analytically.
(5) Document constants/scaling to make the n→∞ bridge rigorous and publication-ready.
